text: Snow swirls around the tall buildings of downtown Chicago
Cars, taxis, limos line the street. A cab pulls up and MA in tuxedo moves into:
THROUGH arriving guests we PICK UP the Man climbing stair to the ballroom.

The Man hands his coat to coat check woman and thanks her When he turns we get our first view of DR. RICHARD KIMBLE a tall, athletic man, with a trim beard. He moves from the outer lobby into a fabulously decorated ballroom where a fashion show is taking place as a medica fundraiser. Doctors and their spouses, hospital brass and sponsors mingle. Women sit near the runway watching the  models. Men talk by the bar. The room is packed. A banner over the rostrum says: "CHILDREN'S RESEARCH AND
Kimble is handed a glass of champagne, which he promptly  sets on another waiter's passing tray.
Richard... DR. ROBERTS, a large surgeon, pulls Kimble over to a grou of surgeons gathered around a bar. Smoking cigars.
Cancun. Nat just talked everybody  into it... A hospital equipment rep, NAT, is buying drinks.
So, what's the deal? If the hospital  buys ten new -
No, no, no, no strings attached, Dr.  Kimble. Industrial Hospital Supply  has no ulterior motives.
On the house, huh? (to bartender)
Tonic water with lime. Everyone agrees.
Never get me to sell my soul for one of those trips... His tone silences the group. Kimble takes his drink.
(to Nat)
... But if you get any more Bulls  tickets, Nat, give me a call. The group laughs, Kimble extracts himself and CREDITS
Moving through the crowd.
Nearly gets hit in the follow-through of an imaginary  golf swing.
You're slicing, Dave. Don't turn  your hip. He keeps moving.
Thanks, Richard...
KATHY WAHLUND, totally out of her element amid the formal elegance around her. She wears a leather jacket over  T-shirt and stares at the action on the fashion runway.
(dripping sarcasm)
I'm so glad you talked me into  coming, Richard... I can pick my cruise wardrobe.
It's for a good cause, Kath...  Besides you need to get out of the lab more. Your electron microscope is starting to give you a tan. She smiles. He moves on.
Kimble continues down the bar when he spots a friend...
Hey, Jim. DR. JAMES NICHOLS turns, smiles. Mid-40s, head of the  University Hospital. He is a fit contemporary.

Richard, I just saw someone who  wanted to meet you... Just then Kimble spots an attractive WOMAN, late thirties wearing a drop-dead, simple black gown. She's surrounded a group of men hanging on her every word. She and Kimble  catch a look and hold it.
Richard Kimble... Alex Lentz. Alex is working on the RDU90 trials for  Devlin-Macgregor. Kimble turns to meet DR. ALEXANDER LENTZ, late 30s, tan,  smiling. Lentz extends his hand...
Dr. Kimble... Sorry, we've been  trading phone calls last few days  ... something about a biopsy report  I returned to you?
(suddenly attentive)
Yeah... Three. Livers appeared  hepatetic to me.
I'll be in my office in the morning  and I'll pull up the samples. Is that  a good time for you?
Sure.
(holds Kimble's look,  then to Nichols)
See you, Jim. Lentz moves on. Kimble looks after him a beat, then focus on relocating the Woman he just saw. She's gone. He and  Nichols move together through the party.
(digs in his pocket)
Before I forget, I went by the garage this afternoon and picket up the  Ferrari. Thanks for the loaner again. He hands Kimble a valet ticket.
They fix it this time?
We'll see. They reach the Woman Kimble saw, his wife, HELEN KIMBLE.  Kimble kisses her.
You look fabulous, Helen. He kisses Helen.
Hello, Jim.
(to Kimble)
We've got a court tomorrow at three. Nichols leaves. Kimble looks at his wife.
Well, I've seen everyone, can we  leave?
That would be a little abrupt, don't  you think?

A table for ten. Kimble and Helen introduce themselves to others at table ant sit across from each other. Kimble sits between two doctors' wives. One, NOW EAU WIFE mid-thirties, bedecked in jewels and loud dress, the othe OLDER WIFE. Helen sits between their husbands who are trying to impre her with the details of their boring studies as CREDITS  CONTINUE... INTERCUTTING WITH the fashion, catches of dialog and cour changes, Kimble and Helen demonstrate an oft-used exchang of glances: Kimble, while gracious to his dinner partners catches Helen's eye and makes smiling, subtle movements t his watch or a look to the door to indicate he's clearly  ready to leave. On the receiving end, Helen, the gatekeep of their social propriety, indicates with equal subtlety: "not yet." As we MOVE AROUND the table we hear: "Where's your husband on staff?" "My husband's an orthopo at Northwestern." "I'm working on a new technique..."  "That's fascinating..." "That's quite a marvelous dress  you're wearing." "Do you like it? My husband says it's a  'four-fracture number."' "Honey." (A look from her husban Kimble shares a look with Helen. He subtly motions to his watch: time go to, and mouths the word: "now." She shakes her head.
(to table)

I told my husband that he was going  to kill us if he didn't stop  operating. What with this AIDS thing,  he's putting us all at risk. Helen and Kimble absorb this comment without reaction, sh a look. Helen mouths the word: "Now."
(to her dinner partners)
I'm sorry, I have to get my husband  home. They say their good-byes and pass Nichols' table. Nichols shakes his friend's hand in passing. From across the room see Lentz watching.
Kimble and Helen driving home. She runs her fingers throu his hair as he drives.
You looked handsome tonight...
Thank you... He smiles to himself, seems to enjoy the compliment too m for Helen. Her smile becomes playful, mischievous.
Uh, huh... most men in a tuxedo look  like waiters...
But me?
You looked more like... a band  director. He stops at red light, leans over and kisses her. Light  changes and neither notice. Slowly their kiss breaks.
Are we home yet?...
Kimble pulls up in front of his house. Suddenly both his  PAGER and CAR PHONE RING at the same time.
(to phone)
Dr. Kimble (suddenly attentive)
When? Okay, tell them I'll be there  in ten minutes. He hangs up.
Tim's got a problem. Helen kisses him again, opens the door.
Call me on your way home. CREDITS END as we -
Kimble, wearing scrubs but without head gear, moves down  stairs to the OR hall. He sticks his head into the operating room.
Cavalry's here. Two harried surgeons look up, glad to see him.
Kimble begins scrubbing as the RESIDENT comes out to brin him up to speed.
Patient is a male, forty-three. We  pulled his gall bladder and the  bleeding started.
What's his pro time?
(concerned)
He's at 36 seconds. We got a major  bleeder in here.
You talk to the family?
None. He's off the street.

Operation in progress. Top medical facility filled with  trained professionals and state of the art equipment. Kim is assisted across the table by the chief Resident. Both  working so intently they never look at each other as they talk...
(to Anesthesiologist)
Okay... I'm clamping. Can he  tolerate it?
He's a very sick guy.
Do we have a choice?
Go for it.
Marie, give me a clamp... MARIE, the scrub nurse, passes him the instrument and Kim and the other SURGEON continue to work with the Resident  assisting.
(never looking up)
Your husband know you're here tonight, Marie?... What about this liver?
History's sketchy. Could be an  alcoholic.
Who referred him?
He's on a drug protocol. RDU90. Kimble looks up and shares a look with the chief Resident over their masks, then back to work.

The wave of the future... Marie, you  told Frank yet? Frank is so jealous  of this late night thing we've got  going here... This should hold him.  Bleeding's stopped. Let's get a  biopsy... (to circulating nurse)
Send it downstairs and make sure you  get Kath her slice.
You staying for the closing, Rich? Kimble moves away and sheds his gloves and gown.
No. I got a date.
Kimble throws away his hat and mask. The door opens behin him; it is the other Surgeon.
Hey, Richard... Kimble turns.
Thanks.
Kimble driving through empty Chicago streets toward home. He is on phone, waits for answer.
Hi. I'm five minutes away...
Helen on the phone, downstairs. She is still in her gown an afghan around her shoulders. She's been reading.
I'm glad it went well. I'll see you  in a minute. Helen hangs up phone, turns out the light and starts up t stairs.
Kimble driving.

Helen moves down the hall toward the dressing room/closet Opens the door to large closet dressing room and turns on the light. Nothing. She starts to leave and decides to cl one of the interior closet doors. She starts to slide the door closed when - wham! A hand reaches out and clutches her by the neck. Helen  claws and scratches to get free and in her struggle her  string of pearls bursts... ... and a single pearl bounces out of the bedroom... roll across the landing to the stairs, stopping three steps fr the top.
Snow swirls around the street as Kimble's car pulls into driveway. On the third floor, we see a bedroom light stil on.
A GRANDFATHER CLOCK TICKS softly. Kimble tosses his keys the entry table, picks up a stack of mail on the table an calls up the stairs.
I'm home. Did you hear who won the  Bulls game? No answer. He steps into the:

The wall phone shows a line in use. Kimble notices it. Th WASHER BUZZES, he switches the clothes from washer to dry and STARTS the MACHINE. Takes a bottle of wine and two  glassesand leaves the kitchen.
Lies on the floor, beside Helen's legs and the receiver o phone, off the hook. A man's rubber-gloved hand picks up gun.
Kimble starts up the stairs to the bedroom...
Helen's hand reaches out presses the cradle down, dials
Climbing the stairs... suddenly stops. A small white ball on the stairs. He bends down and picks it up... a pearl.
Helen? Silence. He can see directly into the bedroom. It's quiet Too quiet. He notices a lampshade on the floor.

Kimble moves slowly to the opened doorway. And just befor he enters he sees a large form in the crack behind the do Adrenal surge. Kimble slams the door back on the figure knocking the gun free. Before Kimble can move to it a forearm flattens him The attacker immediately goes for the gun. Kimble grabs a leg and twists him down, the man's fingers hit the gun,  sending it skittering across the hardwood floor of the  landing and over the edge - three flights to the entry  hall below. SIRENS can be heard. Distant but APPROACHING. The man kicks free and tries to flee. This time Kimble  catches an arm and twists it at an unnatural angle. To hi shock, the limb detaches between the shoulder and elbow. Kimble looks at the arm in his hands - it's hollow.  Electrodes are visible inside - then to the man's unreada face... The SIRENS are LOUDER... Before Kimble can recover, the One-Armed Man knocks Kimbl down and grabs back his arm. He runs down the stairs. Kimble pulls himself up and starts to follow but is stopp by a VOICE behind him in the bedroom...
He's here... still in the house...
Lying by the bed, Helen Kimble, clutches the phone with o hand, her head with the other.
Did I hear you right? Your attacker  is still in the house? Ma'am?
He's trying to kill me... Kimble appears. Helen drops the phone when she sees him.
Will you repeat that please?
(to Kimble)
Richard... He's trying to kill me...  my head.
Two Chicago police cars wheel to the curb, COPS move quic to the house.
Kimble moves to her. Sees the necklace of bruises where s was held down and choked. And then a bullet wound in her  leg. She's already going into shock. Her speech turns thi
Hang on, babe... going to be all  right. Her fingernails dig into Kimble's arm, trying to hold on.

My head. Richard my hold me. Her eyes slip away from his. He peels away the hand on he head - and sees raw pummeled brain staring back and reali she won't be all right. CAMERA SWINGS DOWN TO the dropped phone.
... Hello. You said his name is  Richard? Ma'am, can you talk to me?  Ma'am?
The Cops enter the house. See the .38 lying on the floor. Covering each other, they move quickly up the stairs - gu drawn.
Third floor. The First Cop, gun drawn, turns the corner o Kimble's bedroom and finds: Kimble holding his dead wife. Blood on his hands.
Move away from her.
Kimble, numbed by the event, washes the blood off his han in the kitchen sink. A cop takes his blood-stained tux  jacket, and another hands him a parka.
The street is filled with Chicago police cars, curious  neighbors, television news vans, etc. Kimble is helped into a police car as the coroner's van  arrives. He pauses a moment to watch as we hear.
Can you give us a little more to go  on besides the fact that he had an  artificial arm? What kind of gun was it, Doc?

CAMERA FINDS Kimble in an interview room. He is in "why"  shock. "Why her." "Why me?" Says nothing. Two Detectives: KELLY and ROSETTI. Kelly, the questioner, is overweight,  aggressive. He shifts his gun on his hip so he can sit do
It was .38... I think. I only saw it  for a second. I knocked it out of  his hand. As Kimble is questioned we INTERCUT WITH flashes of the  murder scene being processed:
Forensics technicians photograph the .38 at the base of t stairs.
Do you own a gun, Dr. Kimble?
Yes.
What kind of gun?
A .38 Smith.
Did you have your key with you tonight,  Dr. Kimble?
Checking doors of house for signs of forcible entry.
PHONE RINGS. Rosetti answers it. Kimble watches him write something down, he slides it to Kelly.
Your wife was loaded wasn't she? I mean, she was worth qu a bit of money.
Kimble looks up at the two cops. For the first time he se to sense something aggressive in their questioning. They no longer seem on the same team.
What's going on here? This guy was  trying to rob us. The two cops stare at Kimble.
You guys have got to be out of your  minds. I didn't kill my wife! He gets up to go. A cop blocks his path. He turns and loo at Kelly.
Let's start over, Dr. Kimble. What'd  you have for breakfast?
Kimble in his tuxedo shirt and black tie holds a booking  number plate in front of him as a mug shot is taken...  front, then side.
We're all adults here so I'll lay it out...
Chicago Sun-Times has a photograph of Kimble spread acros the front page.
... If you two come up with a deal,  I'll listen, but let me make one  thing perfectly clear.
Salesmen continue to hawk sets. Kimble's photograph comes up on a hundred TV monitors across the store.
Police are revealing no details in  the case against Chicago surgeon...
Kimble lays on his bunk. Thinking...
... It's an election year...

CAMERA MOVES THROUGH smoke-fillet room to find tough FEMA PROSECUTOR, a man in late forties, WALTER GUTHERIE, and S ON the source of the voice we've been hearing and the cig JUDGE BENNETT, late fifties. Fair but, no nonsense, polit survivor.
... and this case is a heater. It  will not end up a bench trial...
Richard Kimble in County lockup fatigues and a navy watch moves down long corridor, escorted by GUARD.
We've had private investigators  interview over a hundred amputees,  Richard...
Walter Gutherie, his attorney, stands by a window looking out at the yard. Another attorney, RANDOLPH, watches  Gutherie.
... We can't find this guy.
I know what I saw, Walter.

I put you up on the stand to say what  you saw without anything that  remotely smells like proof and the  State's attorney is going to take  this one-armed man story and run it  up our ass. (he holds Kimble's look)
Look, Richard, you're paying us a  lot of money to defend you... A plea to second degree -
I didn't kill my wife.
Kimble being escorted back to the courtroom. A guard carr his suit in a bag. He is taunted by other prisoners.
You're a successful upper middle  class white man charged in a  violent crime...
On the other side of the door is the courtroom. A sheriff deputy hands Kimble (now wearing his suit), a small plast bag. In it we see his wedding band.
It's a circumstantial case, but it's  also a jury trial. We play 'em, they  play 'em...
Richard Kimble sits at defense table... watches prosecuto chat with Helen's relatives. Media anchors glare at him.
... But if we lose, we lose big.  Just remember, they're lined up a  block long to have your hide.
A crime scene photograph.
On the stand.
No forcible entry was found. From  the beginning of the investigation,  it did not appear to be a break-in.  Nothing was missing.
On the stand.
The defendant's prints were found on the neck, gun, bullets, and lamp...  no other sets were fount other than  the deceased.
Impassive. Attentive. His "peers." They listen to the  recording of the 911 tape.
Did I hear you right? Your attacker  is still in the house? Ma'am?
He's trving to kill me...
Will you repeat that please?
Richard... He's trying to kill me...
A few members lean over to make notes. It's powerful take out of context.
Dr. Nichols. You are aware that  Richard Kimble was the only  beneficiary of Helen Kimble's estate. 12 million dollars roughly.
I was aware of that. The money meant  nothing to him.
Yet in your presence, Richard Kimble  once said that 'if he had Helen's  money he could find plenty of uses.' Did he not?
We were talking about -
Yes or no? Nichols' look tells us everything... Yes.
On the stand.
The wound to the head caused a  massive hemorrhage to the brain. It  took from five to seven minutes for  her to die... A woman in the jury reacts. Kimble notices.
On the stand. He finishes his moving description of the  events. We see some of the jury has been moved.
... And I was holding her when the  officers came in. Gutherie returns to his seat. The Prosecutor moves to the jury. He begins slowly but his questions pick up strength
How tall was this man, Dr. Kimble?
I can't be sure. We were, mostly on  the floor, fighting... I couldn't -
Did that fight cause the scratches  on your face and arms?
No. As I explained -
And how did this man enter your  house?
I don't know -
And you probably don't know why your  wife told the emergency operator You  were her attacker?
She didn't -
Your name is Richard, isn't it? Your  gun is a .38, isn't it? Your prints  were on the gun, the bullets, the  lamp, her neck, weren't they?
Look...
Weren't they?
Richard Kimble sits behind the desk, but already he's a  shadow of the man we knew before, stares ahead passively Judge Bennett delivers the sentencing to hushed courtroom

After careful and studied review of  all evidence presented during each  phase of this proceeding, and  because aggravated circumstances,  detailed at length, were present  the night of January 20th. Kimble is silent, stunned, but all around him the sentenc shockwaves through the courtroom. Reporters push out rear doors. Prosecutors share a look - with a hangman's  satisfaction. Nichols, watching behind Kimble's table,  lowers his head. Disbelief.
He remains silent. Kimble is pulled gently to his feet by bailiff. Gutherie whispers an "I'm sorry." Kimble doesn't hear it.
Therefore, it is the decision of  this court... Looks over his shoulder to the emptying courtroom. Faces  stare back.
Judge Bennett's V.O. CONTINUES over: A locker opening. Inside, a profusion of chrome and nicke plating. Jailhouse jewelry. Handcuffs dragged out. Action checked.
... that you be remanded to Menard  State penitentiary...

Slapped down over wrists, ratcheting down tight. Ankle cuffs dragged out. Pant legs raised, canvas shoes  exposed. Cuffs clamped down on ankles. CHAINS RATTLED out. Snaked across the floor. Looped aroun waists and locked to handcuffs to form belly chains.
... where you will serve a sentence  of life imprisonment without  possibility of parole.

head_text.subj: EXT . SALLY PORT, (COOK COW TY JAIL)

text: The chain gang exits through the sally port. Kimble and  three other prisoners. Jailers escort them to... An Illinois Department of Corrections guard moves alongsi checking the undercarriage with a pole-mounted mirror. The GAVEL CRACKS as we -
Locking wire mesh cage inside bus. An old DIESEL COUGHS to life.
Main gates open. The BUS GRINDS onto the streets.

The four prisoners sit scattered, still cuffed but no lon chained together. Near the front, PRISONER #1 is eyeing.. The two prison guards seated beyond the caged door. YOUNG GUARD lighting a smoke. OLD GUARD drowsing. Shotguns  bouncing on their knees. Prisoner #l shifts his gaze to.. The driver. Pistol on his hip.
The BUS RUMBLES north, heading towards the horizon.
PRISONER #1 rises. Through caging:
Hey. Illinois penal regulations  require a meal for transport rides of four hours or more. Young Guard shakes his head. "Fucking jailhouse lawyers." Checks his watch: 4:00.

Jack! Feedin' time. Old Guard yawns to his feet, unhooks a key-ring from his  belt. Young Guard stows his shotgun in the weapons locker PRISONER #2 looks at Kimble. Kimble stirs awake... watche the cage door open, Young Guard moving back. And across t aisle... PRISONER #3, a big man named COPELAND, wags his head  between his knees. Something slides out of his shirt and  CLANKS to the dimpled steel floor. It's a razor sharp  plastic shank. Heart quickening, Kimble looks forward. Young Guard is  handing a petrified sandwich to Prisoner #1. Kimble snaps a look back to Copeland, who palms the shank.
Breathe, and you're first. Old Guard watches from the open cage door, shotgun  carelessly ready. Young Guard reaches Kimble and extends a sandwich. Kimble doesn't respond.
Suit yourself. He offers the sandwich to Copeland. In the exchange,  sandwich drops. Copeland leans down for it. Up front, Old Guard yawns again just as...

Look out! Too late... Jackknifing up, Copeland drives the shank int Young Guard's gut. Prisoner #2 dives for Young Guard's holster. As the gun c out, Young Guard gets a hand on it. A SHOT FIRES... Jolting Old Guard. He chambers his shotgun. Kimble hits t floor. The Old Guard jams a key into the cage door and su inside, but... Prisoner #1 broadsides Old Guard. SHOTGUN DISCHARGES...  Opening a big Gainsburger hole in the driver. He sinks un the steering wheel. A knee hits the accelerator. The CAGE DOOR SLAMS locked behind the Old Guard.
As the bus careens off the road, accelerating.

Young Guard wrestles gun from Prisoner #2 and FIRES, kill prisoner #2. Copeland grapples with wounded Young Guard. Old Guard shotgun-butts Prisoner #1, flips the gun, PUMPS ONE ROUND into the man's chest. Dead. He turns just as...
As the driverless BUS BUCKS ant BANGS over open ground.
Old Guard reloads. Copeland drops down behind a seat. Old Guard jams his SHOTGUN under the seat. But just as th Old Guard pulls the trigger the bus jerks. The SHOT goes  off target as...
The BUS ROARS into a gravel embankment. ROARS up the slop and CRASHES down on its side - sliding to a stop at the  bottom of a small ravine.

ENGINE DIES. Dusty silence. We don't know up from down. On his knees, Old Guard makes his way to the driver. Find him dead. Now a SOUND. Old Guard whips his shotgun around at... Kimble. Rising between the seats. A hairy beat. Old Guard might kill him just to finish thi off. But a GROAN turns Old Guard's head. Young Guard, trying to hold his guts in. Old Guart turns find Kimble.
(to Kimble)
You. You're a doctor. C'mere. He slides to the Young Guard as the Old Guard scrounges u medical kit, shoves Kimble down on Young Guard.

Do something. Kimble looks at his cuffs. "In these?" Old Guard digs out his key ring and unlocks Kimble's hands - only his hands. Kimble opens medical kit. It's been ransacked - just  Band-Aids now. Kimble looks into the wound.
He isn't going to make it unless he  gets to a hospital. Fast.
In this delicate moment a SHIVER runs through the bus. Is just settling? With other things to worry about, Kimble tries to stop Yo Guard's bleeding.
We see Copeland, alive. The crash has ripped the bars fro back window and shattered the glass. He works to get out opening.
A second SHIVER ripples through the bus, stronger. Kimble retracts his hands to touch a metal panel - and feels a  growing vibration.
Just where the hell are we? The Old Guard feels it too. He gets down on his knees and looks out one of the shattered, barred windows.
Oh, shit...
The bus lies across railroad tracks. A not-too-distant be grows bright by the light of an approaching train.
Kimble sees: Old Guard fights the cage door. Kimble lunge to his side.
It's locked. Where're your keys?
Downtrack, one Cyclops light appears.

Kimble spots keys. Pitches them to Old Guard. Drags Young Guard to the front for a quick exit. But Old Guard fumble the key-ring, his hands shaking as much as the bus. The train light spider-webs across cracked windows. Kimbl snatches the keys away from the Guard's trembling hands.
Which one? This? This one?! Old Guard gulps a nod. Kimble jams a key in the lock. Thr the door open. Grabs Young Guard.
Help me get him - But Old Guard climbs right over Kimble's back and climbs the shattered windshield.
Copeland escapes through the hole in the back...
... and hits the ground running the other way. The  locomotive's headlight reveals the toppled bus.
Train light grows. A nanosecond of uncertainty: Should  Kimble leave the wounded man? Kimble and the Young Guard  hold a look.
As the WHEELS BRAKE and LOCK.

Kimble struggles out of the bus - pulling the Young Guard behind him. He slings the man clear. SCREECHING death, the TRAIN SKIDS closer. For one heartbeat, Kimble remains perched atop the bus. The train light X-rays him. Kimble leaps. Lands. Rolls. Gains his feet. Tries to spri away but can't: His feet are still chained. He gets off a dozen mincing steps before... IMPACT: A hundred tons of STEEL SLAMS into the bus,  splitting it open. Shrapnel rips through Kimble's thigh, but he stays on his feet, still running feverish half-steps. An EXPLOSION envelops the train. Flames stream down its  flanks. The train burns past the wounded Guard. Kimble looks back, expecting to see the catastrophe behin him. But he gets the shock of his life - of any man's lif Still on its wheels, the locomotive is derailing - and co after him. It's the stuff of nightmares: One little man b chased by a fire-breathing locomotive. The train burrows to a stop. Kimble is suddenly five feet taller, standing on an uphea of earth, staring eyeball-to-eyeball with the train that  nearly devoured him. He pants. Coughs on smoke. Then noti something in his hand. It's the key-ring.
Kimble sits and searches the key-ring for manacle key.  Suddenly a hand reaches down and snatches the key-ring aw
Give me that. Kimble watches as Copeland quickly unlocks both sets of h own chains.

You listen to me. I don't give a  damn which way you go, just don't  follow me. Kimble takes the key as Copeland wraps his chains around arm and runs. Kimble unlocks his leg irons and runs in th other direction - crossing a hilltop in the moonlight.

News and sheriff's department choppers circle billowing  smoke. TILT DOWN to reveal the derailed train. Fire engin hose down the blackened locomotive. Rescue workers work  feverishly with jaws-of-life to get into the mangled  wreckage. Illuminated by spotlights, transportation  investigators in blue coveralls pick through the twisted  remains of the bus. State troopers restrain spectators. Two American-made rental cars pull up. Four deputy U.S.  marshals emerge: BIGGS. Swaggering Midwestern carnivore. Built like a bric shithouse. RENFRO. Bantam-rooster of a man, no more than 140 pounds  fully-equipped. POOLE. Black woman. Nobody minds having her around during nut-cuttin' time. NEWMAN, a scrub-faced G-5. From the second car steps GERARD. He takes in the media  spectacle.
Good lord...

What is this... a circus? As a group they begin moving along the service road above the crash site. Derailed train cars are accortianed below them. They take in the elements of the crash and as they  walk each begins to reveal their U.S. Marshal's credentia Biggs spots something...
Point of impact. ... and branches off.
Biggs, your turn to babysit Newman.
Shit. (to Newman)
Come on. They drop down to the crash site. Poole ant Renfro remain with Gerard. A state TROOPER steps into their path, but falls away whe sees Gerard's Marshall star.
How ya doing? Who's in charge?

Sheriff Rollins. Just follow the  lights - Gerard follows his point to where TV lights illuminate th scene. He shakes his head - it doesn't please him. Renfro and Poole share a look, they seem to know what's  about to happen.

Seated near a tree. A space blanket draped over his  shoulders. He is surrounded by EMT personnel, and a YOUNG SHERIFF, clearly basking in the event. Television remote  news crews are kept only slight back. Gerard appears in t b.g., listening.
... train was bearin' down on us,  fast. I don't know how - it's still  kind of hazy - but I grabbed him and pushed him out of the bus.
You coulda both been killed.
I know, but hell, he's my partner. Woulda done the same for me. The young Sheriff in charge nods, buying the story. Gerar eases forward, displays his badge, interrupts.
Excuse me, Sheriff Rollins? Deputy  U.S. Marshal Samuel Gerard.
(annoyed)
I'll be with you in a minute. The television lights widen to illuminate Gerard. He shie his eyes. The Sheriff opens a file and produces fax-photo of all four prisoners.
(to Old Guard)
For the record. These three dead.  And this one... He switches to a photo of Kimble.
Well, everything happened so fast... (bites lip, decides)
Huh-uh. Don't think he made it. Sheriff eyes the wreckage that could entomb a hundred  prisoners, then files Kimble's fax-photo with the others.
You get some rest. He pats the Guard on the shoulder and approaches Gerard.
Looks like you came a long way for  nothing. My men've already done a  thorough search from point of  impact and found nothing.
Biggs and Newman stop by the muddy culvert. Biggs sees  something. He orders Newman into the muck after it.
Aware of media, proceeds patiently with the young Sheriff
With all due respect, may I suggest  check-points starting at a 15-mile  radius on I-57, I-24, Route 13 east  of -

Whoa, whoa, whoa... For what?  Prisoners are all dead. The only  thing check-points will do is get a  lot of good people out here frantic  and flood my office with calls. Gerard finally touches eyeballs with the young Sheriff an we get our first taste of Gerard at close range.
(beat)
Well, shit, Sheriff, I'd hate for  that to happen... So, I'll be  taking over the investigation.
On whose authority?

By authority of the Governor of the  State of Illinois and the office of the United States Marshal, 5th  District Northern Illinois... Poole produces State and Federal authorization documents  from one of her pockets and hands it to the young Sheriff
(back-down beat)
Okay. You want jurisdiction over  this mess, you got it. (to assistants)

Shut it down. Wyatt Earp is here to mop up for us. He slaps the file of fax-photos at Gerard on his way out. Just as Biggs, spotless, eases ino the group with Kimble' manacles. Behind Biggs we see Newman, covered in mud. Seeing the leg irons, the Sheriff and his deputies pile t a stop. Now Gerard takes his run at Old Guard.

Please, ladies and gentlemen, step back and give this poor man some  room. Like an obedient dog the press backs off, they sense a  change of story and command. Gerard kneels down with Poole and Renfro in front of the  Old Guard. The Sheriff hovers near.
(friendly, to Old  Guard)
Always an interesting thing when we  find leg irons and no legs in them  who held the keys, sir?
Uh, me.
Would you be so kind as to show them to me, sir? Gerard's large hand extends palm up at the Old Guard. The Old Guard pats his pockets, comes up empty. He eyes t press hovering just out of earshot.
Second chance. Poole reopens the file of photos in front of the man. The Old Guard can't take it - points to Kimble's photo.
(cracking)
He mighta got out.
Thank you.
What the hell is this? A minute ago  you tell me he's part of the  wreckage, now you're -

Renfro - Take that bus apart. I want  an accurate body count. Poole - Set  up operations right here. He stops and looks into the TV lights and starts moving  downtrack. The media and State Police move with him like  Israelites behind Moses.

Ladies and gentlemen... our  fugitive's been on the run for  ninety minutes. Average foot speed  over uneven ground - barring injury  is approximately four miles an hour,  giving us a radius of six miles. I  want a hard-target search of any  residence, gas station, farmhouse,  henhouse, doghouse and outhouse in  that area. Check-points go up at  15 miles. (to media)
You got that? Good. Now, turn  those damn things off and get out  of our way.
ROARS... just above the treetops. Helicopter speeds up a dark river. Its tracking beam illuminates the river bank.
Flashing lights. Two highway patrol cars set up roadblock The SQUAWK of police RADIOS breaks the rural quiet. A mom later a HELICOPTER ROARS overhead.

Kimble moves down train tracks. His jumpsuit is wet with  blood from the gash. He pauses and checks the wound. He's going to need stitches. Far down the tracks he sees glow of town lights. He keeps moving.
Kimble crosses a tressel, keeps running toward the direct of the lights. A junk yard by railroad tracks and a road. Signs along th road show we're on the edge of town. One says: Hospital-1 mile.

Kimble runs from a streak up to the railroad tracks. As h nears the junk yard and road he sees the hospital sign.  He's close but he can't go into the hospital in his priso jumpsuit. He leans against a wrecked car and catches his  breath. Just then a tow truck pulling a car on its hook, turns of the road and parks next to the tracks. Kimble ducks for  cover behind the wrecked car. The driver climbs out, dumps his coveralls in the front  seat and closes the door. He moves toward a house across the tracks, then forgets  something and returns to the cab. He throws open the door and grabs lunch box off the seat - and we notice the  coveralls missing from the seat. As the driver returns to the house we MOVE TO the opposit side of the car to find Kimble, ducked beneath the window clutching the coveralls.

A crude headquarters is set up beneath a tent, near the  crash site. Maps are laid out on tables. Power and phone  lines are pulled down from the lines running along the  tracks. Renfro supervises the electronics. Poole handles phones, takes a report from the field and  relays it to Gerard.
Blood trail found. Two miles  southwest.
(to Biggs)
Type it and match it against all  four prisoners. (to Renfro)
Renfro, get an I.D. fax on Kimble to  every local hospital. (to Newman)
Newman... Newman appears.
Yes, sir...
I need some coffee. As Newman steps off, everyone turns at sound of SHOUTING  from the train crash.
A RESCUE WORKER shouts up to others.
Hey, one's alive!

Loading dock outside the E.R. A WORKER stacks boxes of fo outside kitchen entrance. Kimble, in the tow truck  operator's coveralls, picks up a box and carries it insid Once inside he branches off down a hallway.
A door opens on a long hallway. A DOCTOR, CHILD with a  bandaged hand, and a MOTHER leave a room and walk TOWARD Behind them, Kimble moves down the hall and stops in fron of the doorway.
Kimble closes the door and locks it. Hanging on the back the door we see a doctor's white coat.
An Illinois State Trooper's car pulls up outside.
On it we see: A packaged sterilized bandage, an opened  antiseptic wash, an opened topical anesthetic, and an emp syringe. We PULL BACK to find:
His wound bathed in orange antiseptic wash, three stitche already in. With pair of forceps he picks up the needle a he sutures himself.
At far end of the hall we see a STATE TROPER chatting wit DUTY NURSE at a nurses' station.
Kimble, his bandage already in place, gives himself a sho of antibiotics.
A man, tube in nose, on two I.V.s, lays in bed with eyes  closed. Kimble comes INTO FRAME near his face.

Can you hear me, sir? No response. The man is out of it. Kimble backtracks to t patient's closet and opens it. Hanging inside we see his  clothes. He removes them and notices the man's untouched  breakfast tray.
The Duty Nurse and State Trooper chat when a fax begins  coming through on DESK FAX.
There's your fax...
Kimble dressing in the man's clothes. He eats a piece of  toast - part of the man's breakfast - as he buttons up hi shirt.
His arm slowly reaches out and presses his nurses call  button.

A fax photograph of Richard Kimble slowly comes off the  duty station FAX MACHINE. Next to the machine the  patient's call light comes on. The Duty Nurse, standing with the Highway Trooper, sees t patient's light come on and starts down the hall toward t patient's room.
Kimble shaving when we hear the DUTY NURSE ENTER the  patient's room. He moves OUT OF FRAME.
Mr. Patterson, do you need some more  water?
The Duty Nurse looks from the tray to the man, impressed.
... Oh, you did a good job on this. She takes his empty plastic pitcher and... ... pushes open the bathroom door - no sign of Kimble - a refills the pitcher from the sink.
(over her shoulder,  to patient)
... It does get dry in here, doesn't  it? She doesn't expect an answer, turns OFF the WATER, and go into the main room. As the door closes we see Kimble behi it.

Kimble, clean-shaven, and wearing the patient's glasses a a doctor's white coat, moves down the hall to the emergen room exit. Suddenly the State Trooper steps back from the E.R. admissions desk with his newly received fax, and sta down the corridor toward Kimble. The Trooper looks up as the two men pass...
'Scuse me, Doc?... Kimble turns but continues slowly backing toward the E.R. doors behind him.
... Don't know if you heard or not  but we're looking for an escaped  prisoner from that bus train wreck  'couple hours ago. Thought he might  show up here if he was hurt.
What's he look like? The Trooper looks down at his fact sheet as we see a slow trickle of blood from a shaving nick begin winding down  Kimble's cheek.
(from fax sheet)
Approximately six one, 180 pounds,  brown hair, brown eyes and beard. At the last second Kimble feels the drop of blood and wip it clean as the Trooper looks up.
... Seen anyone that fits that  description?
Every time I look in the mirror ... but without the beard. They laugh.
Excuse me...
Sure. Kimble moves through the E.R. doors as an ambulance parks outside...
Two PARAMEDICS try to take out a patient on a gurney. The lead wheels are stuck.
Here... Kimble helps clear the wheels so the collapsible gurney  comes free.
Thanks, Doc, we had to dig him out  from under a train. As the gurney comes out, Kimble looks right into the face of the Young Guard. The Guard's eyes suddenly open wide.
It's him... It's - Kimble claps the portable oxygen mask back over the Young Guard's mouth and keeps his hand there.
How is he? The Paramedics move him toward the ramp.
He's pretty bad off. Broken leg,  ribs. Concussion. As Kimble moves away...
Tell the E.R. doctor he's also got  a perforated spleen. He's gone... The two Paramedics share a look as they whis the Young Guard inside.
(impressed)
Jesus, how could he tell that from  looking at his face?
Kimble climbs behind the wheel.
A full communications link is in place. Deputy marshals answer phones, work faxes, add informatio to a situation board. Troopers bring in information. Pool calls Gerard.
Background just came in from  Chicago.
Hit me. Renfro and Poole lay out the details. The download of  information comes clear and fast.
Richard David Kimble. Vascular  Surgeon. Convicted of first-degree  murder in the killing of his wife.  Pleaded innocent. Claimed a  one-armed -
Let's not retry the case. Priors and accomplices? Gerard steps up the hillside out of sight of the  investigation to take a leak. Followed by Renfro and Pool
None. No previous arrests. Poole takes up a position discreetly behind tree as Gerar unzips his fly and relieves himself.
Sealed juvie record? Poole calls out from behind tree.
Nothing. Total cherry.
Relatives? Children?
No relatives.
One child. A son. Died in drowning  accident three years ago.
Girl friends? Ex-wives? Friends?  Combinations of the above?
Lot of friends. Doctors. Hospital  staff. Gerard zips up.
Start there. Authorize taps. Cover his lawyer first.
Never get it.
Bet me. Renfro won't take it.
Have Stevens go to Judge Rubin,  he'll sign 'em. ... Biggs charges up the hillside.
DeLange Hospital. Wounded guard  swears to High Holy he saw Kimble  right there in the hallway.  Ambulance, missing too.
Gerard moves quickly to the map.
Give me a time.

O-nine-thirty. Twenty minutes ago. Gerard redraws the circle of units. No longer are we  covering a fifty-mile radius. The circle is redrawn,  tightened, with the hospital as its center. The  triangulation is set.
The ambulance follows three cars toward a rural railroad  crossing.
... We're waiting up here in Canton. Wondering if you heard anything on  this Kimble chase -
Kimble behind the wheel as he approaches the railroad  crossing. The biocom monitors police chatter:
Two-twelve-A, be advised that all  discussion on this matter is to be  conducted on a tactical frequency  - either Channel K or Z. Over. Frequency goes dead. Kimble looks THROUGH the windshield:

An arrow points toward Canton, two miles. The cars in front slow as the railroad crossing signal  suddenly activates and the bars begin to drop. Kimble pop the SIREN and hurriedly snakes through the crossing and  heads in the opposite direction... but his maneuver gets  attention.
Truck driver watches Kimble cut through the crossing and  reaches for his C.B. radio.
Poole hangs up phone.
Ambulance just spotted two miles  west of Doverville. Heading north  on State road 53. Renfro turns to the map and marks it. The circle is much  smaller.
Running outta map, Sam. The crash site and hospital are already marked. Gerard is ready to move.
Just the way we want it. Okay,  people, let's button up. They move off to waiting State Trooper cars and helicopte
Kimble driving down a rural road. He flips down visor and eyeballs folded roadmap...
... The ambulance crests a hill. In the distance we see t Grosvner Viaduct and the Barkley Dam.
Blowing other traffic off the road, WHOOPING CRUISERS and G-cars stream south through the rugged rural terrain of  Southern Illinois. Overtaking them all, a CHOPPER THUNDER overhead.
Heading into hilly terrain. Down below we see the ambulan Inside the helicopter Gerard eyes the terrain.
(into radio)
We've got a visual... (to Gerard)
He's heading toward the viaduct.
Seal it up.
The two-lane road disappears into long tunnel. Three hund feet below the road tumbles the Tennessee River. The Barkley Dam rises ahead. Kimble's AMBULANCE ROARS int the tunnel.
Suddenly sees the helicopter setting down ahead of him at the mouth of the tunnel. Kimble slams on brakes and turns to retreat.
Illinois Highway Patrol cars pull to a stop at the far  entrance. Light flares. Set out road blocks.
Gerard steps out followed by Renfro and Poole.
Comes to a stop, blocking traffic in both directions.  Immediately HORNS begin BLARING.
Trooper pulls up. Biggs and Newman behind Kimble blocking the other end. Troopers with guns drawn block the exits. The P.A. from a State patrol car blares:
Please remain in your vehicles and  lock your doors. Repeat, please  remain in -
Poole and Renfro materialize already decked out in Kevlar They're jacked up and ready to rock. Renfro hands Gerard vest.
Got him. Gerard unholsters a 40 caliber, Glock model 22.
Okay, ladies and gentlemen hard  part's over. He starts into the tunnel.
(to radio)
We're movin' in.

Weapons drawn, but held discreetly at their sides, three  silhouettes enter. Drivers who hadn't heeded the Troopers P.A. warnings take one look at Gerard and quickly climb  back inside and lock their doors. Biggs, Renfro and Poole fan out to the sides and give the middle to Gerard. The tunnel is quickly quiet. Kimble huddles at mid-tunnel. He's trapped. Drops to the  ground beneath the truck. His heart pounding, brain  clicking, fighting panic. Suddenly he realizes he's in wa Running water.
They reach the mid-tunnel area. No Kimble. Biggs looks  around, beneath vehicles. Gerard listens. Poole looks  confused.
Where'd he go? Gerard spots the trickle of water. He backtracks it until he finds a loose grate in the pavement. Man-size.
Biggs, Renfro with me.

Kimble splashes blindly through ankle-deep sluice. He slo at forking tunnels to catch his breath and pick a directi A DULL ROAR comes from somewhere - from everywhere. He wh off his jacket and slings it down a tunnel, then continue straight ahead. Somewhere behind, lights probe splash-patterns on the con wall - telltale signs of Kimble's passing. The lights bel to... Gerard, Biggs and Renfro. They push on, soon reaching the forking tunnels. Renfro finds the jacket ant splash signs
Channel Three. They conform their radios. Splitting up, Biggs and Renfro left. Gerard - straight ahead.
Kimble. Bracing with all four limbs. Negotiating a mossy  downslope.
Biggs and Renfro. Sweeping his light as he advances.  Searching for splash-patterns.
(into shoulder-mike)
Nothing yet.
Gerard. Probing a branch-off tunnel with his light. About pass, he notices scrapings on the mossy walls of the  branch-off tunnel. Hand marks?
(into radio)
Got a possible here. Stand by. He stows his light but hangs onto the Glock. Bracing with three limbs

Gerard begins the tricky descent. Slips once. Recovers.  Slips again... ... and tumbles out of control. GUN and RADIO CLATTER AWA Scrabbling for purchase, he finally snags An overhead pip Gerard stabilizes. Sweeps his light to locate his Glock,  lying down-tunnel. He eases toward it. But another hand g there first. It's Kimble. Face dark and desperate. Dangerous. Hand  flexing on the pistol. They lock eyes for a beat.
I didn't kill my wife.
So, you didn't kill your wife. Not my problem. An adrenal beat. For a moment they hold a look. Then the  silence is broken by Gerard's radio.
Gerard? You there? Gerard looks for his radio, then back at Kimble - he's go Instantly Gerard reaches for his ankle - and pulls a back piece.
As Renfro hears FOOTSTEPS POUNDING his way.
Gerard charges down the tunnel. From a side tunnel, Renfr appears, almost colliding. Biggs follows...
Straight ahead!

Kimble sticks Gerard's gun into his waist band to balance in the tunnel. He spills around a corner and stops. Ahead lies an orb of light. The tunnel ends. The NOISE is  incredible. Kimble moves to the end of the tunnel and  stops.

Water pours from the tunnel into the spillway of Barkley disappearing into a veil of mist below - a great cauldron mists. No rocks. None visible at least. He hears the MARSHALS behind him - COMING CLOSER.
Gerard and Renfro turn the corner. Renfro drops into a  shooting stance.
Turn around, hands over your head.  And get down on the ground. For a moment Kimble eyes Gerard.

Your choice, Kimble... Kimble turns his back on the Marshals, stares again at th water. Slowly he puts his hands over his head. Gerard put up his gun and pulls his handcuffs. He moves through the  water toward Kimble.
Get down on your knees. Kimble bends slowly, stares down into the falls, hears th footsteps get closer, then does the unthinkable. He jumps
Biggs moving to the top of the massive dam sees Kimble le into the sheet of water spilling over dam and disappear i the mists below. He can't believe his eyes.
Renfro lowers his gun.
(amazed)
Son of a bitch... It's the most amazing thing he's ever seen...
He stands at the mouth of the tunnel staring down. He  stares down into the mists. Impressed. It has told him  something invaluable about this fugitive.
Gerard scrambles out of the tunnels to the top of the dam near Biggs, just as squad cars, troopers and the search  helicopter converge on the site.
Far downriver a figure fights through a snag in the bend. The snag - a tree branch - breaks away and heads down  stream. Hanging onto the branch we see Kimble.
Below the dam and spillway. Troopers in waders search the shallows, deputies beat bushes along the shore. Farther out we see a dredge boat slowly working the water
Gerard watches the dredge cage come up again. As if with  the next pass it will prove him the victor. The HEAD  ILLINOIS TROOPER CAPTAIN approaches.
Running out of daylight, Inspector.
Lights and generators are coming,  Captain.
Look, I don't mean to tell you your  job, but maybe one person in a  million could've survived that fall. The guy's fish food. Gerard turns and brings his look to bear on the Captain.
Then find me the fish that ate him. He turns and heads to a waiting helicopter.
Kimble runs through the woods. He staggers, his arm hooks sapling which spins him to the ground. He lays motionless exhausted.
Helen in bed. Kimble's hand comes INTO FRAME and touches  her shoulder. She turns toward Kimble as he moves INTO  FRAME and kisses her.
Helen tosses her head back. She wears white silk pajamas  and smiles down AT us. A hand reaches up and unbuttons th top two buttons of her top. Then Kimble moves up INTO FRA as we -
Helen running down beach TOWARD us. Embraces Kimble as we
Helen's head comes up out of a pool. Hair tossed back, sh smiles as we -
Helen exiting Kimble's car the night of the murder. She  looks back at Kimble, framed by the door frame, ant smile
Good-bye. I love you. Again... Then again... then:
Kimble comes out of his sleep with a start. Shivering. He remembers where he is. His breathing returns to normal.
Kimble moves across a river trestle and disappears into  tunnel.
Kimble on pay phone in the rear of the store waits for  party  to answer. An old lady and her mother shop. Across the store a pharmacist watches Kimble.
Kimbles watches the boys as he waits for answer. We hear  RINGING, then a receptionist answers:
The law offices of Gutherie, Morgan  and Wainwright.
Walter Gutherie please.

I'm sorry, Mr. Gutherie has left  for the day, would you like his  voice mail? Kimble hangs up and moves down an aisle, stopping in fron of the hair color. He takes a box of black hair dye off t shelf and looks at the instructions. When he looks up he  sees the pharmacist looking at him.
A roadside diner. Kimble, his hair now black, and wearing new pair of Wranglers, hooded sweatshirt and a duffle coa moves down the road to the diner.
Kimble enters. He sits at the counter and a sparky OLDER  WAITRESS, late, mid-forties, with strong good looks and  tough smile fills his coffee cup before he even asks.
Need to look at the menu?
Some soup, please.

Good choice. She marks her pad and leaves. Sights ant sounds around  Kimble begins to occupy his attention: A dishwasher buses a tub of dishes back to the kitchen. H stares at him. A farmer sitting at a table stares at Kimble, Kimble look away. A man at the pay phone seems to be staring at him. he calling the police? Everyone seems to be looking at hi Someone stops in front of him. A young waitress serves hi his soup. Where's the first waitress? Takes a few sips of soup. Out of the corner of his eye he sees: The Older Waitress putting on her coat to leave. Is she  going to report him? He fights the paranoia. A NEWS REPORT on the TELEVISION gets his attention.

A report on the escape. A television reporter describes t chase for Kimble; his jump at the dam and his presumed de from the fall. Kimble decides it's time to leave. He drops some money on the counter and exits.
Kimble moves across the parking lot trying not to run unt he's out of sight of the diner. Once free of the lights o the diner he starts running and disappears into the night

Kimble running down the road. Fields stretch out on both  sides of the highway. Open land. From behind him we sudde hear the sound of POLICE SIRENS. For a moment Kimble move faster, then as the SIRENS COME CLOSER, his sprint drops a jog... to a walk, until finally he stops and waits for inevitable... But the flashing lights suddenly rip past h chasing a speeder. They weren't after him after all. Kimb looks at himself. He's shaking. A moment later he is lit by headlights. A car pulls up ne to him, passenger window rolls down...
Need a ride? Kimble stares at her.
Which way are you going? She smiles and points in the direction her car is traveli They hold a look as we hear:
We feel confident about the I.D.

A quiet house on a quiet street out from town. A homeless woman picks through garbage. A garbage truck moves slowly down the street. A plumbing truck parked along a curb. Ju early morning traffic. We see Renfro and Newman watch the house from across the  street, behind a deserted house. Gerard joins them. We se that Biggs is in the plumbing truck. Poole is the homeles woman picking through the garbage. Newman hands Gerard a  radio.
Local officials were about to wet  their pants to move in.
I bet they were. (to radio)
Where's the woman?
In the plumbing truck. He triggers his mike.
(into radio)
Same room.
(into radio)

Okay... I'll take front. Biggs and  Renfro, rear. Poole, handle support.  I don't want anyone hurt. Stay  outside unless called. Radios on  three. The deputies prepare their weapons. Newman checks his  service issue .38, stares at Gerard's Glock.
Uh, just want me to wait here, sir?
Hell, no. You're with me, Newman.  Let's go.
DOOR CRASHES open, splintering the deadbolt right out of  the door.
U.S. Marshals. Down! Down!
Textbook perfect, Gerard and Newman rush into front room.
Down the hall a man's figure streaks across a doorway OUT OF VIEW. A woman in the rear of the house BEGINS SCREAMING.
Motions Newman to the left to check the door off the livi room while he moves down the main hall into the back  bedroom.
Clearly unnerved by the screaming woman, Newman opens doo off the living room. The door opens into a smaller bedroo He steps into -
It's empty. Gerard appears at the other (hallway) door to the bedroom.

Gerard motions Newman on to the door to the bathroom and  continues down the hall into the back bedroom where the  woman continues SCREAMING. He ignores her. His feet move  silently, heel-to-toe. He checks the bathroom as Newman  opens his connecting door - empty - then moves on toward  the doorway to the kitchen. Gerard moves to the kitchen doorway. Running out of house He braces himself swings into the kitchen - it too is emp Suddenly Gerard gets the bad feeling he's passed his prey
Newman looks around, suddenly scared. The only place he  didn't search was behind the bedroom door. He turns just
Surges out, knocks Newman's gun from his hand. In a flash Copeland yanks Newman's arm behind his back and presses a knife against the deputy's neck and moves him out of the  room. We...
He hears Copeland moving somewhere in the front of the ho
I got your man! Now I want outta  here! Gerard moves back through the bedroom past the SCREAMING  woman. He locks in on the voice and sound of the moving  fugitive.
Copeland listens but gets no response from Gerard. He bac through the second bedroom door, pulling Newman into the
Newman's eyes are pure terror - the blade pressed against his throat.
(to Gerard)
You hear me? I said, I want out or  I'll cut your man's throat!
Keeps moving down the hallway, through first bedroom, pau at door to the second bedroom and chooses his course.

Copeland positions himself between the bedroom door and t hallway opening. He's troubled he can't hear Gerard. Suddenly he hears a NOISE behind him at the bedroom door whips Newman around and we see: A shoe hits the floor. Copeland realizes his mistake too  late. He turns back to the hallway and there is Gerard. He never blinks. FIRES once killing Copeland instantly.  The knife falls to the floor. Newman clutches his head,  stunned but unhurt. Gerard now turns to the screaming woman behind him in the bedroom doorway.
Shut up. She does. Immediately.

As coroners and tactical police mop up. Gerard moves acro the yard, sips coffee from Styrofoam cup. He stops at a  sheriff's car, Newman sits on back seat, shaken, nearly  hysterical, clutching his ear.
My ear... I can't hear a thing out  of it. I can't believe you did that!
You think I should have bargained  with him, don't you?
Yes. You could've missed! You  could've killed me!
Yeah, you're absolutely right. I  could've. They hold a look.
How bad's your ear?
Terrible. I probably have permanent  hearing damage.
Let me see it. Newman leans toward him. Gerard speaks into his ear.
I don't bargain. Gerard leaves. Newman watches him - realizing what a trul unsettling man Gerard is.
Kimble makes call. While he waits for phone to be answere TRAINS COME and GO in the b.g. An EL CROSSES OVERHEAD. Th BELLS of Chicago River DRAWBRIDGE.
Walter. It's Richard.

location: LAW OFFICES OF GUTHERIE, MORGAN AND WAINWRIGHT

text: Walter Gutherie answers phone from his office overlooking Lake Michigan.
Richard... Jesus, why did you run?  Running only makes you look guilty.
I wasn't worrying about appearances,  Walter.
Tell me where you are. I'll come meet you so you can turn yourself  in .
I'm not turning myself in. I need  money. Gutherie is silent. When he speaks again his speech takes the lawyerly tone of a man who's covering his own bases.

Richard. You're asking me to harbor and aid a convicted felon... I can't help you that way. My advice - both  as a friend and as your legal counsel  - is for you to give yourself up.  Now tell me... where are you? Kimble picks up the change in his attorney's tone.
(beat)
St. Louis.
Give me an address. I'll be - CLICK. Gutherie hears the LINE GO DEAD. Kimble's gone.
Kimble stands in the doorway with cup of coffee. He consi his next move. Then seeing bank clock flash the time: 9:3 he knows what that move is.

An upscale mid-town tennis club. Behind glass windows of  the entryway we see tennis courts. From the courts comes Charles Nichols still dressed in his warmups, carrying hi tennis bag. A friendly DESK ATTENDANT Sharon) smiles as h goes by.
See you tomorrow, Dr. Nichols?
Creature of habit, Sharon.
Dr. Nichols leaves the club. He tosses his gym bag into t back of his car and drives off.
As he pulls up to the first stoplight, a homeless man mov toward the driver's side and begins washing his windshiel Nichols waves the man off.
Not today, please. The man shuffles off. Just then a second man appears at h passenger window. He leans down to wave him away
No. Not - ... then stops - the face at his passenger window is  Richard Kimble's.
(stunned)
Oh, my God... Richard... Nichols rolls down the passenger window.
How're you doing, Charlie?
You're alive...
Yeah. And I need your help.
Anything.
I need some money. Whatever you've  got on you.
Of course. Nichols reaches into his gym bag in the backseat and digs for his wallet...
Tell me where you're staying. I'll  get you more money. Some clothes.  Just give me an address...

I'll call you. Kimble glances around, the area is still clear. He looks  back into the car and doesn't see the police car turn the corner and come up the street behind them. Nichols finds his wallet ant hands all the cash he's got Kimble, who quickly pockets it.
I know why you came back - to find  him. If I can help, call me...  Call me. They hold a look. The stoplight changes to green but they don't see it.
Thanks, Charlie...
Here, Richard, take my coat... He reaches into the back for his coat, suddenly police ca behind him POPS its SIREN. Nichols looks into his rearvie mirror. Sees a COP lean out his window.
(to Nichols)
Hey, buddy - green light. Let's go. Nichols looks back at Kimble. He's gone.
REWINDING. The media room - just what it sounds like - banks of audio/video equipment and a sound board. Renfro rewinds the tape. Gerard, Biggs, Poole and Newman.
We've alerted St. Louis P.D
Call them back. Tell them you've  made a mistake.
What?
(to Renfro)
Stop it there. Renfro hits play. Kimble's VOICE is heard again:
Drop the voices. Renfro removes the two voices. What comes up are the
MECHANICAL... TRAINS). Everyone becomes focused to the  sounds now.
(he's heard something)
Listen.
Trains? Traffic?
More... there's a voice in the  background. At first the sound is unrecognizable. A BELL. GRINDING  MECHANICAL. Then a P.A. VOICE on the tape: "Next stop  Merchandise Mart."
That's an El announcement.

And there's no E1 in St. Louis.  Ladies and gentlemen, Richard Kimble is in Chicago. Poole, get his  artwork out to local police and have  C.P.D. check the shelters... Biggs,  bring in the detectives that handled  his case. Instantly the room is in movement.
I'll prepare the press release.
No. Stevens stops.
They don't know he's alive and as  far as Kimble knows we don't either.  I want to keep it that way as long  as we can. Are we clear? The whole group sense Gerard's intensity in regard to  Kimble.
(for the group)
Perfectly. Gerard reflects on a moment of personal satisfaction.
Noah... go to my office and let's  officially take Dr. Kimble out of  purgatory.
Morning roll call. Kimble's photo distributed to cops by  Detectives Kelly and Rosetti.
As of this morning Chicago P.D. was  alerted to the reappearance of  Richard Kimble.
Newman and Poole check train station. Looking for Kimble. They show his photo to homeless people. No help.

location: FRONT OF COOK COW TY HOSPITAL

text: Holding a handkerchief to his face, Kimble moves through  arriving patients and enters Cook County Hospital.
Renfro and Biggs check shelters for Kimble. They show his I.D. to administrator. Look around.
The place is humming now. Detectives Kelly and Rosetti si in front of Gerard. Gerard studies Kimble's file. Renfro  sits in.
Police units have also increased  patrols around homeless shelters and mass transit stations in the city.
Police patrol the platform looking for Kimble.
Kimble moves past security, then pockets the handkerchief turns up a hallway, blending in with the indigents and po
NURSE FLYNN, a woman about 45, attractive, smart, loyal. Poole and Gerard talk to her in an examination room.
I ran his office for twelve years.  Yes, we were very close. But he  wouldn't come to me for help.
Busy with doctors, orderlies and street people. Kimble mo down hallway and enters.

He moves into the room and takes a new patient form, look around. SEE BACK INTO the office area of the clinic. It  could be any hospital clinic from this view. But as Kimble turns to leave we see a PATIENT waiting to called. On his lap we see a prosthetic arm. Kimble looks from the arm to the man.
Good morning.
Good morning. As he turns to leave we hear:
Don't underestimate this guy...
Dr. Roberts from the party, talks to Biggs and Gerard as takes off scrubs to get into shower.
R.K.'s one smart, cold sonofabitch... He did her, no question.
Kimble moves down the hallway containing the janitor's  locker room. Janitors move in and out the door.

Gerard walks through Kimble's house. The art and most of  the furniture is gone. Books are in boxes and shopping  bags around the room. Plastic covers the remaining pieces of furniture. Gerard stares at the empty walls. Shadows on the walls sh where the art once hung. Gerard pauses, tries to absorb t place. He takes a book from one of the bags and looks at

Kimble moves past the lockers, racks and boxes of cleanin supplies, stops at a board listing work schedules, vacati leaves, locker numbers. Behind him a LOCKER SLAMS. As a  janitor moves off to the showers we see his locker did no close but remains slightly ajar from the impact.
Door opens revealing the janitor's clip on I.D. hanging  from a green shirt. Kimble steals it.
Gerard looks at the two detectives.
Gentlemen, I appreciate the  cooperation of the Chicago police... He moves toward them.
A SALESMAN stands on ladder looking through pants sizes.
Did you say, 38/34?
WHAP. A folded pair of green janitor's pants drops onto t counter in front of Kimble. He already has the green shir to the uniform.
Photographed.
Kimble takes the finished photos from the delivery tray.
Was there anything in your initial  investigation that would make you  think Kimble would come back to  Chicago.
The man definitely has friends here.
What about lady friends?
Not that we found.
A card on a community bulletin board advertises a basemen apartment for rent.
What about the man he claimed  attacked his wife? Kimble pulls the notice from the board as we -
Kelly and Rossetti share a look, a smile.
Right... You ever been downwind of a  stockyard when the breeze is  blowing? That's where we were  sitting when Richard Kimble told that one...
Kimble knocks at door. It is opened to reveal a PUNK KID, 18-20. He calls to someone O.S.
A light comes on and an OLD POLISH WOMAN, her stockings  rolled down her shins, leads the way down the basement  stairs. The Punk Kid stands at the top of the stairs,  watches Kimble.
We found nothing. The Polish woman shows him a spare but sufficient bed and nightstand set up. She points to door leading up to the  street.

Kimble also at work at the bedside table. He carefully cu out his do-it-yourself photograph and places it over the  existing photograph on the hospital I.D. The name on the  I.D. says: Desmondo Jose Ruiz. Then he places a thin piec of lamination plastic and trims the edges. Kimble defaces the plastic to give it rough look, then  examines the finished product not bad.
If this guy existed believe me  someone would've found him.
He raises an eyebrow.
Of medical residents. Two photographs next to each other. young Richard Kimble and Charles Nichols.

Richard Kimble... I saw him two  days ago. WE PULL BACK to see: Gerard studying the photos. Renfro  looks up like someone's bitten him. He, Biggs and Gerard in Nichols' administrative office. Gleaming. Filled with  awards and photos of Nichols and influential people. Nich hangs up his lab coat and slips back into his suitcoat. H shows no sign of nervousness.
He stopped me in my car. I gave him  some money.
Where was this?
Outside our tennis - (correcting himself)
- my tennis club. Gerard moves around Nichols' office taking in the details
Did he ask you for help?
I volunteered. He wouldn't accept  it.
Why do you think he came back to  Chicago?
He didn't tell me.
I didn't ask you that, sir. I'm sure he was trying to protect you from  having to lie for him. Gerard continues to move around the room, study prints,  books, drawings, awards and photos.
If you're really his friend, you'll  help us bring him in unharmed.
Why, so he can go back to prison?  If you want help, gentlemen, you've  come to the wrong man. Gerard finds a photo of Nichols and a gleaming Ferrari.

Dr. Nichols, last year the U.S.  Marshals' office closed out 11,003  warrants... 10,975 of those were  captured. The twenty-eight others  thought they were smarter than  us... Now they're dead. (re: the photo)
Nice car. Gerard puts the photo down.
Gerard and his deputies leave Nichols' outer office.  Gerard clearly feels he's come to the right man.
Stay on him.

Kimble mopping the trauma room hallway. The hallway elbow around a corner and Kimble stands less than ten feet from a door that is marked: "PROSTHETIC CLINIC" He watches a technician leave the clinic and mops closer the doorway, and fails to see an attractive WOMAN DOCTOR  with white coat and stethoscope draped around her neck tu the corner behind him ant step on the freshly mopped  section. Head down, she is completely absorbed in a file and doesn see the wet floor until she slips slightly, looks up but  keeps walking.
Where's Rudy?
They said he's sick.
Didn't they tell you to put up the  sign?
Uhhh. No they didn't.
Put up the 'wet floor' sign before  someone gets hurt. She keeps going.
(mumbles)
Asshole. She looks back at Kimble.
What did you say?
Nothing. Anne keeps moving off toward trauma hall. He watches her  turn the corner to the trauma hallway.

Kimble enters the dimly lit prosthetics lab. He moves silently among the casts and prosthetics of arms hands, legs hanging from the ceiling. Cables and electron equipment are on the counters. He leaves the lab and moves into the office section of th Prosthetic Clinic. He passes a computer room and finally  reaches the office. He is about to enter when a woman's  voice stops him.
Hey, Ricky... Weren't you just in  here? Kimble turns to see a PROSTHETIC TECHNICIAN. A large woma with glasses. She stands with a partially finished  prosthetic arm.
The one-armed man's arm coming off in the fight.
Sorry, I thought you were Ricky.
(stumbling)
No... I've got to clean the blinds in the office. Want me to wait till  you're finished?
Naw... I'm going to be here all  night. You won't bother me. She slips on a pair of headphones and goes back to work.
Kimble cleaning the blinds, keeps an eye on the Technicia who is listening to music on her Walkman. She is carefull painting a section of the arm. Not watching Kimble.
Opened.

Nimble looks over his shoulder. The Technician doesn't se him. A Prosthetic Clinic Operations Manual is removed from she Photographs of prosthetic arms. Kimble shifts the materia into his clothes, closes his coat and suddenly he stops.

Kimble waits for the elevator. The folders in his uniform shift and he tries to rearrange them. When he turns back  we see Anne Eastman beside him. Her I.D. says:  "ANNE EASTMAN". She sees him doing the rearranging. The elevator arrives. They step into:
Anne moves to the back. Kimble on the other side.
Hey, how're you doing?
Fine.
You find that sign?
Yes, I did.
You called me an asshole.
Excuse me. I was having a bad  shift. They laugh. They reach ground level and step out together
You worked at other hospitals?
Lots of them over the years. Here,  long ago. Hasn't changed much.
I bet it hasn't. See you. They part ways. Kimble continues out the door. Anne stops and watches him leave.
Kimble sits on the night train going home. He begins look at his information.

Afternoon light comes in Kimble's basement windows. Sheet of Prosthetic Clinic patient material are spread over  Kimble's bed, floor. Kimble searches through the document making notes. He studies photos of attachments. Cable  attachments. Joints. Electronics. Pins. straps... looking for a key to the identity of the one-armed man. Finally he stops. He finds the flyer in his pocket, puts on the bedside table and moves to sink. He wets a towel a covers his face. Draws a cool damp breath. Lays back on bed amid the  Prosthetic Clinic material.
Kimble pulls the arm. It separates in the one-armed man's sleeve. Wrenches. Dis-articulates.
Reacts in pain. Again. (NOTE: We sense Kimble's mind  returning to something. Getting closer to the key...)
Escaping the bedroom. We hear his FOOTSTEPS DOWN the  STAIRS... a DOOR SLAM. FOOTSTEPS again. Another DOOR SLAMS, but this time the sound is distinctly different... a CAR DOOR.
Kimble yanks the wet rag from his face, his senses alert. Listening, he hears: FOOTSTEPS are real, just outside and MOVING TOWARD him.
A car door slams. We see unmarked police cars pulling up front of the apartment. Cops are moving toward the house.
Kimble turns off his light, moves from the bed to the win Carefully looks out:
Unmarked police cars in front of the house, looking, movi his way.

Kimble moves instinctively to the back door. He starts to open it but through the dirty window, he see the back courtyard covered by more cops. Kimble moves back toward the front. Unsure of his next mo he's sweating, preparing for the worst. He watches the TAC team charge the house but instead of  charging through the basement door they move up the front steps and into the house overhead. Overhead he hears the SCREAMING from the arresting cops.
Kimble SEES the Punk Kid try to escape out the back. He  runs, sees cops and runs toward Kimble's basement door,  actually reaching it before he is caught by the cops and pulled away.
Moves toward the front window and watches cops lead the  Punk Kid out to the car. POLICE RADIOS call the other cops to stand down. Kimble moves slowly to his front door. Looks out.
Cops put the young man into an unmarked police car. His  grandmother, the Polish woman, follows them, crying.
Kimble leans against the wall, exhausted.
Kimble carries his cleaning tray down busy hallway just  outside of the Prosthetic Clinic and stops.
Two cops talk outside the Prosthetic Clinic.
Kimble backs to a safe place in the trauma hallway to wai for them to leave.
The Punk Kid is handcuffed to a bench as a cop works on a report. Suddenly the Kid notices something that gets his  attention.
A wanted poster of Kimble over the cop's head.
The Kid sees - Wanted for Murder - realizes who it is.
(to cop)
Hey. Hey! I know that guy! The cop looks up, sees Kimble's poster and then back at t Kid.

Kimble moves toward prosthetic clinic. In passing through the trauma hallway he becomes aware of a crisis developin A major accident has happened, victims are being brought The P.A. CALLS for doctors. STATIC.

Elevator doors open as orderlies bring in new patients.  Some walk, some are helped by family and police. Nurses  direct traffic. Orders fly. Medicines are called. Family members yell for doctors. Ask for the injured. Anne picks up the pace with an ORDERLY wheeling a gurney carrying a young patient,  a BOY.
What happened?
A bus flipped off the overpass. Got at least twenty more coming in.
What about this one here?
Fractured sternum. X-ray's coming  up. Anne checks the boy's chart.
Okay, we've got to get some room in this hallway, people. Orderlies quickly move the non-life-threatening patients of the hall. Still more help is needed. Anne spots Kimble

Hey, take this one up the hall to Critical Care. Kimble nods. Anne moves to another patient. Kimble grabs the kid's gurney and begins wheeling it up t hall. As he pushes he looks at the kid's X-rays. Anne looks up, barks another order, then suddenly sees Ki pushing the gurney and looking at the film.
Tries to negotiate through the incoming patients to get a better look, but Kimble is gone. She goes back to work.
He wheels the Boy's gurney into an elevator. The doors  close.
Kimble wheels the gurney down the hall and stops the Boy  on the scrub threshold to the O.R. and stops a SURGEON.
Hey. Hey! A Surgeon pauses and eyes Kimble's janitor suit and the  gurney.
They just sent this one up. He takes a look at the Boy's chart and grabs the X-rays a yells to O.R. nurse.
Bob! Get this one into room four,  stat. He looks up, Kimble is gone.

Kimble enters the Prosthetic Clinic computer room. The  Technician from the day before is listening to her Walkma sees Kimble and waves. Kimble waves back and turns into t glass-walled computer room and closes the door. He closes the blinds and turns on the computer.
The crisis has wound down. Anne moves into the room and  begins checking patients. She stops a unit nurse, GLADYS.
Gladys, where's the boy I sent down  with the janitor?
What boy?
The one with the fractured sternum.
He never came in here.
Kimble scans DOS files, each an eight-letter enigma. Find one with promise and loads it up.
Wrong... He backs up and tries another file.
Kimble knows he's got it.
Kimble keys in these responses:
Anne comes out of the stairwell and stops the Surgeon we  saw with Kimble.
Dave, did you see a janitor come up  here earlier?
Yeah, he brought a kid up. (handing her the chart)
Anne, did you write the orders? I  couldn't make out the signature...
I saw -
(in a hurry now)
Whoever did knew what the hell he  was doing. Kid's a hair away from  a ruptured aorta. He heads to the operating room, leaving her stunned. She  stares at the scrawled orders.
A "PLEASE WAIT" message appears on the screen. We hear th COMPUTER PROCESSING, searching, narrowing. The screen flashes:
Seventy-five. Hell, yes. Kimble types in another defining characteristic...  Residence: Illinois. Again he waits. Rattles the blinds to make it seem like h cleaning. The list shortens.
What else?
Prosecutor stands before the jury.
... murdering Helen Wills Kimble the night of January 20.

Kimble types in: "Candidates having adjustment appointmen between January 21, and February 1, 1993." Kimble waits. Sixty-five names come up. Again too many.  Kimble's reached a dead end. Kimble thinks.
The fight with the One-Armed Man.
Something has clicked in his memory.
Kimble stands beneath the hanging artificial limbs. He  takes down an arm, works the joint.
Kimble fights the One-Armed Man. He wrenches the man's  prosthetic arm.
He moves it again. Harder, at an awkward angle.
Kimble wrenches the arm...
The joint strains.
Kimble wrenches it and it BREAKS.
A detailed diagram of arm construction.
Kimble makes notes.
Anne rides the elevator back to trauma. She's thinking.

Joint repair list between January 21-April 21... Five nam come up with Greater Chicago addresses. Kimble hits print. The MACHINE begins PRINTING. Kimble  looks up at the Prosthetic Clinic Technician - she is  listening to her headphones, can't hear the printer. He  continues to shake the blinds.
Kimble leaves Prosthetic Clinic and starts down the hall  for the exit when a voice stops him.
Do you have a particular interest in our patients' x-rays? Kimble turns to see Anne coming toward him.
What do you mean?
I saw you looking at that boy's  chest film. She moves in on him. He eyes the exit.
It's a hobby of mine -
What other hobbies do you have?  Brain surgery?
What do you want? She reaches him.
I want to know how that kid ended  up in surgery.
I'm a janitor. I did what I was  told.
Bullshit. Who changed those orders? They hold a look. She knows. He takes a step back and she pulls his I.D.
You stand right here. I'm calling  security. Kimble runs. Anne turns to call security but doesn't. She stares after Kimble.
Kimble's room being searched by the marshals. Gerard find the flyer Kimble was handed on his way out the door. On i we see: COOK COUNTY HOSPITAL.
Anne and Gerard stand in the hallway. Gerard studies the
A man posing as a janitor orders an  emergency operation and all you do  is pull his I.D.?
(firmly)
A little boy's alive today because  he did something. Gerard watches her eyes carefully.
So, you weren't aware that when he  escaped he was being transported to  Menard State Prison to begin a term  of life imprisonment.
For what?
For murdering his wife. Clearly this is news to Anne. Gerard almost smiles at her surprise.
Thank you for your help, Doctor. He moves to the position Anne saw Kimble with the kid's  gurney. Trying to imagine what Kimble was doing at that  place. Renfro and the other deputies converge.
What I can't figure is, if you were  Kimble, why'd you take a major  league chance of hanging around a  trauma ward? Gerard considers this as a Man passes him. Gerard notices something.

The place would be crawling with cops. Slowly Gerard separates from the group of deputies and  follows the Man down the hall. The Man Gerard is following turns the corner to the  Prosthetic hallway and realizing Gerard is following him, holds the hallway door open for Gerard.
Can I help you find something?
Thank you, sir, I think you already  have. We see the Man has a prosthetic arm and that they are out the door marked: "PROSTHETIC CLINIC"
Restaurant deserted at this hour. Kimble makes calls.
Yes... This is Dr. Elway at Cook  County. I'm doing follow-up work for  the Prosthetic Clinic on Matthew  Zelick... (beat)
He did... I'm terribly sorry. No,  I'll correct our files. Thank you. He scratches through another name. Three left. He dials  another number.

Gerard and his deputies inside the Prosthetic Clinic. Artificial limbs are being tested, fitted. A technician  fits a demonstration model on Biggs while Gerard and Pool work with the director of the institute and a data operat at the computer.
The onearmed man. Missing the right or left hand?
Right. The operator enters that information. Dropping the number 250... as Poole continues.
Kimble on phone. He hangs up and scratches through anothe name. Two left. He dials another number.
Poole looks up from her file to the computer screen. The  number drops to 117...
Location of the attachment.
(from the report)
Mid-humerus.
The next name is "Clive Driscoll." Kimble on phone, waits for answer.
